\textrm{{User} \ }u\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Receive (and store) from the server the list of ciphertexts $\{e_{u,v}\}_{v\in U_{2}}$ (and infer the set $U_{2}$). If the list is of size $<t$, abort.} \par\itemize@item@[--] For each other user $v\in U_{2}\setminus\{u\}$, compute $s_{u,v}\leftarrow\textrm{{KA.agree}}(s_{u}^{SK},s_{v}^{PK})$ and expand this value using a $\mathrm{\mathbf{PRG}}$ into a random vector $\bm{p}_{u,v}=\gamma_{u,v}\cdot\textrm{{PRG}}(s_{u,v})$, where $\gamma_{u,v}=1$ when $u>v$, and $\gamma_{u,v}=-1$ when $u<v$ (note that $\bm{p}_{u,v}+\bm{p}_{v,u}=0\forall u\neq v$). Define $\bm{p}_{u,u}=0$. \par\itemize@item@[--] Compute the user's own private mask vector $\bm{p}_{u}=\textrm{{PRG}}(b_{u})$ and the masked perturbed input $\bm{y}_{u}\leftarrow\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u}+\bm{p}_{u}+\sum_{v\in U_{2}}\bm{p}_{u,v}\pmod{R}$. \par\itemize@item@[--] If any of the above operations (key agreement, PRG) fails, abort. Otherwise, send $\bm{y}_{u}$ to the server and move to the next round. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. references:
We present Dordis, a distributed differentially private
FL framework that is highly efficient and resilient to client dropout.
Specifically, we develop a novel â€˜add-then-removeâ€™ scheme that enforces a required noise level precisely in each training round, even if some sampled clients drop out.
This ensures that the privacy budget is utilized prudently, despite unpredictable client dynamics.
To boost performance, Dordis operates as a distributed parallel architecture via encapsulating the communication and computation operations into stages.
It automatically divides the global model aggregation into several chunk-aggregation tasks and pipelines them for optimal speedup.
Large-scale deployment evaluations demonstrate that Dordis efficiently handles client dropout in various realistic FL scenarios, achieving the optimal privacy-utility tradeoff and accelerating training by up to 2.4Ã—\times compared to existing solutions.

Abstracting Workflow for Generality.Â Â  Unlike traditional ML workflows, which involve a computation graph of neural network with general consensus established on their representationÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016a; Jia etÂ al., 2019), secure aggregation protocols combine both computation and communication, with no standardized approach.
Nonetheless, we notice that secure aggregation protocols are often designed as multi-round server-client interactions.
We thus propose to represent the workflow of a secure aggregation protocol as a sequence of â€˜round-trip stepsâ€™, each of which starts with the serverâ€™s request for some data and ends with the related clientsâ€™ responses.
Furthermore, we associate each step with its dominant system resource and group consecutive steps that use the same resource into a stage which corresponds to the minimum scheduling unit in pipelining.
For example, TableÂ 1 illustrates our representation of a distributed DP protocol using SecAggÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017a), where all 11 steps are grouped into 5 stages.

Our noise enforcement scheme, XNoise, ensures that the target privacy level is consistently attained, even when client dropout occurs, without impairing model utility (sectionÂ 6.2).
The runtime overhead is deemed acceptable even without pipeline acceleration, and the network overhead remains constant despite the modelâ€™s expanding size (sectionÂ 6.3).

We also report the final model accuracy in TableÂ 2.
Compared to Orig, which fails to achieve the target privacy in the presence
of client dropout, our XNoise converges at the same speed
(as exemplified by the learning curves in FigureÂ 9 where the per-round dropout rate is 20%)
and induces no more than 0.9% accuracy loss as it uses the minimum noise required to maintain the desired level of privacy.
It should be noted that the accuracies obtained with Dordis are similar to those in other FL studies that use distributed DPÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021a; Agarwal etÂ al., 2021; Stevens etÂ al., 2022).
This is because FL clients have limited and non-IID data, and model updates are discretized for secure aggregation.
Additionally, in some cases, XNoise achieves higher accuracy than Orig, even though the latter uses less noise.
This is because the stochasticity introduced by slight additional random noise can act as a regularizer to reduce overfittingÂ (Neelakantan etÂ al., 2015; Liu etÂ al., 2020).

XNoise Induces Acceptable Overhead in Time.Â Â 
FigureÂ 10 shows the average round time, broken down into two components: â€˜aggâ€™, related to distributed DP operations, and â€˜otherâ€™, related to remaining workflow operations such as model training.
In a plain execution without pipeline acceleration (yellow bars for Orig and XNoise in FigureÂ 10(a) toÂ 10(d) and FigureÂ 10(i) toÂ 10(l)), XNoise extends the round time
by up to 34% given no dropout, and by up to 19%, 13%, and 12% when the per-round dropout rate is 10%, 20%, and 30%, respectively.
This implies a negative relationship between the time cost and dropout severity, as the more clients that drop out, the less noise the server needs to remove in XNoise (DefinitionÂ 2).
Such a relationship also implies an acceptable overhead in practice, as Dordis targets scenarios with client dropout.
Moreover, the overhead can be further reduced by Dordisâ€™s pipeline acceleration (sectionÂ 6.4).

XNoiseâ€™s Network Overhead is Invariant of Model Size.Â Â 
The noise decomposition in XNoise allows for the transmission of noise seeds (sectionÂ 3.1).
To examine its practical advantage over â€˜rebasingâ€™, we benchmark their additional network footprint induced to a surviving client compared to Orig.
As specified in real deployments, the size of a model weight, noise seed, Shamir share of seed, ciphertext of a share (the latter three are configured for XNoise only) are set to 2.5, 32, 16, and 120 in bytes, respectively.
As seen in TableÂ 3, as the model size increases, the network overhead of XNoise remains constant and low, while that of â€˜rebasingâ€™ grows linearly.
The communication time of â€˜rebasingâ€™ can thus be prohibitive when the model is large in size (e.g., Â¿500M) and/or the clientâ€™s bandwidth is low (e.g., Â¡1Mbps).
Additionally, a large overhead makes client failures in the middle of noise removal more likely, which â€˜rebasingâ€™ cannot handle without the loss of model utility (sectionÂ 3.1).

It is important to highlight that the cost of Dordis is dependent on the number of sampled clients rather than the overall population size.
In FL systems, although the population can be extensive, the number of sampled clients is typically restricted to a few hundredÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021b; Bonawitz etÂ al., 2019).
This limitation is due to the fact that involving additional clients beyond a certain threshold only yields marginal benefits in terms of accelerating convergenceÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Wang etÂ al., 2021).
Therefore, the results presented in TableÂ 3 are evaluated from practical settings of sample sizes and are applicable in real-world scenarios.

In this hybrid, SIM has access to all the inputs of honest parties ğš«Uâˆ–Csubscriptğš«ğ‘ˆğ¶\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C}, and gUâˆ–Csubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ˆğ¶g_{U\setminus C}, and runs the full protocol with MCsubscriptğ‘€ğ¶M_{C}, which includes simulating the random oracle â€˜on the flyâ€™ (using a dynamically generated table), the PKI, and the rest of the Setup phase. The view of the adversary here is the same as the previous one.

Support for Diverse Distributed DP Algorithms.Â Â 
As outlined in SectionÂ 5, Dordis offers developers the capability to implement customized distributed DP algorithms using the provided generic programming interface.
To facilitate this, TableÂ 4 presents the base classes that can be tailored to specific requirements.

The first base class, ProtocolServer, serves as a foundation for implementing various server-side workflows (as exemplified in TableÂ 1).
To streamline the development of computation logic, Dordis supplies established communication primitives based on Socket.IOÂ (pyt, [n.â€‰d.])), which developers can employ to handle server-client interactions effectively.
To specify the execution order and resource dependencies of different operations, Dordis further provides the set_graph_dict() method, allowing developers to annotate and aid Dordis in planning an optimized pipeline acceleration (seeÂ sectionÂ 4.2).

Support for Diverse Applications.Â Â 
TableÂ 4 also demonstrates that Dordis offers developers the flexibility to extend the aggregation framework to power various privacy-sensitive applications beyond FL. This versatility allows for seamless integration into different use cases.
To achieve this, developers can leverage the AppServer class by overriding the use_output() method, which specifies how the aggregated result is utilized by the server.
Likewise, developers can instantiate their own AppClient and customize its behavior by overriding two methods. Firstly, the prepare_data() method can be modified to define how a clientâ€™s data is generated. Secondly, the use_output() method can be configured to determine how the aggregated result is consumed by the client.
We have made Dordis open-source and warmly welcome contributions from the research community to further advance privacy-preserving data analytics research.

C1: Our noise enforcement scheme, XNoise, guarantees the consistent achievement of the desired privacy level, even in the presence of client dropout, while maintaining the model utility.
This claim is supported by the simulation experiment (E1) outlined inÂ sectionÂ 6.2, with the corresponding results presented in FigureÂ 8, TableÂ 2, and FigureÂ 9.

C2: The XNoise scheme introduces acceptable runtime overhead, with the network overhead being scalable with respect to the modelâ€™s expanding size. S
This can be proven by the cluster experiment (E2) described inÂ 6.3 whose results are reported in FigureÂ 10 and TableÂ 3.

S4.T1.caption: Table 1. Abstracting the workflow of dropout-resilient distributed DP into multiple stages for pipelined execution.
S4.T1.table:
Step Operation Stage (Resource)
1 Clients encode updates. 1 (c-comp)
2 Clients generate security keys.
3 Clients establish shared secrets.
4 Clients mask encoded updates.
5 Clients upload masked updates. 2 (comm)
6 Server deals with dropout. 3 (s-comp)
7 Server computes aggregate update.
8 Server updates the global model.
9 Server dispatches the aggregate. 4 (comm)
10 Clients decode the aggregate. 5 (c-comp)
11 Clients use the aggregate.
references:

A3.T4.caption: Table 4. The programming interface provided for developers to customize their own distributed DP algorithms and applications.
A3.T4.table:
Category Base Class Customization Instruction
Distributed DP ProtocolServer Overwrite set_graph_dict() to specify the distributed DP workflow for pipeline plan generation. Create one method for coordinating each operation, e.g., encode_data() to instruct DP encoding.
ProtocolClient Overwrite set_routine() to specify the handler for each serverâ€™s request. Create one method for processing each serverâ€™s request, e.g., encode_data() to encode local input on request.
DPHandler Overwrite init_params() to specify how to initialize DP parameters, encode_data() and decode_data() to how to perform DP encoding and decoding given a chunk of input, respectively.
AEHandler, KAHandler, PGHandler, SSHandler Overwrite the respective functionality for necessary security primitives: authenticated encryption, key agreement, pseudorandom generator, and secret sharing.
Application AppServer Overwrite use_output() to specify how the server uses the output of distributed DP.
AppClient Overwrite prepare_data() and use_output() to specify how a client prepares the input and consumes the output of distributed DP, respectively.
